id.desc: Component ID, not specified by default. If specified, it can be used to refer the component in option or API.

name.desc: Series name used for displaying in tooltip and filtering with legend, or updating data and configuration with setOption.

radarIndex.desc: Index of radar component that radar chart uses.

symbol.desc:
Symbol of .

Icon types provided by ECharts includes

'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

If symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:

(value: Array|number, params: Object) => string

The first parameter value is the value in data, and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

symbolSize.desc:
symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

If size of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:

(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number|Array

The first parameter value is the value in data, and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

symbolRotate.desc:
Rotate degree of symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

If rotation of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:

(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number

The first parameter value is the value in data, and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

Callback is supported since 4.8.0 .

symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, [0, '50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

label.desc: Text label of , to explain some data information about graphic item like value, name and so on. label is placed under itemStyle in ECharts 2.x. In ECharts 3, to make the configuration structure flatter, labelis taken to be at the same level with itemStyle, and has emphasis as itemStyle does.

label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,



}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

label.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

label.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.textBorderColor.desc:
Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.textBorderColor.desc:
Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.rich.<style_name>.textShadowOffset.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

labelLayout.desc:
Since v5.0.0

Unified layout configuration of labels.

It provide a chance to adjust the labels' (x, y) position, alignment based on the original layout each series provides.

This option can be a callback with following parameters.

// corresponding index of data
dataIndex: number
// corresponding type of data. Only available in graph, in which it can be 'node' or 'edge'
dataType?: string
// corresponding index of series
seriesIndex: number
// Displayed text of label.
text: string
// Bounding rectangle of label.
labelRect: {x: number, y: number, width: number, height: number}
// Horizontal alignment of label.
align: 'left' | 'center' | 'right'
// Vertical alignment of label.
verticalAlign: 'top' | 'middle' | 'bottom'
// Bounding rectangle of the element corresponding to.
rect: {x: number, y: number, width: number, height: number}
// Default points array of labelLine. Currently only provided in pie and funnel series.
// It's null in other series.
labelLinePoints?: number[][]

Example:

Align the labels on the right. Left 10px margin to the edge.

labelLayout(params) {
    return {
        x: params.rect.x + 10,
        y: params.rect.y + params.rect.height / 2,
        verticalAlign: 'middle',
        align: 'left'
    }
}

Set the text size based on the size of element bounding rectangle.


labelLayout(params) {
    return {
        fontSize: Math.max(params.rect.width / 10, 5)
    };
}

labelLayout.hideOverlap.desc:
If hide the overlapped labels.

The following example shows how to hide the overlapped labels in graph automatically when zooming.

labelLayout.moveOverlap.desc:
If move the overlapped labels to avoid overlapping.

Currently supported configurations:

  • 'shiftX' Place the labels on horizontal direction sequencely, used when aligned horizontally.
  • 'shiftY' Place the labels on vertial direction sequencely, used when aligned vertically.

The following example shows how to use moverOverlap: 'shiftY' to place the labels aligned vertically.

labelLayout.x.desc: The x position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as '20%'.

labelLayout.y.desc: The y position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as '20%'.

labelLayout.dx.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the x direction. Can be used with x.

labelLayout.dy.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the y direction. Can be used with y

labelLayout.width.desc: The width of displayed label. Can be used with overflow to constraint the label in a fixed width

labelLayout.height.desc: The height of displayed label. Can be used with lineOverflow to constraint the label in a fixed height.

labelLayout.align.desc: The horizontal alignment of the label. Can be 'left', 'center', 'right'.

labelLayout.verticalAlign.desc: The vertical alignment of the label. Can be 'top', 'middle', 'bottom'.

labelLayout.draggable.desc: Whether to allow the user to adjust the position by dragging.

labelLayout.labelLinePoints.desc:
The array of the three points of the label guide line. The format is:

[[x, y], [x, y], [x, y]]

It is often used in pie charts to fine-tune the guide line that has been calculated. Usually not recommended to set it in other situations.

itemStyle.desc: Item style of the inflection point of the lines.

itemStyle.color.desc:
color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

Supports callback functions, in the form of:

(params: Object) => Color

Input parameters are seriesIndex, dataIndex, data, value, and etc. of data item.

itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

itemStyle.borderType.desc: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.

itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

For example:

    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat

For example:

{

emphasis.focus.desc:
Since v5.0.0

When the data is highlighted, whether to fade out of other data to focus the highlighted. The following configurations are supported:

  • 'none' Do not fade out other data, it's by default.
  • 'self' Only focus (not fade out) the element of the currently highlighted data.
  • 'series' Focus on all elements of the series which the currently highlighted data belongs to.

Example: 

emphasis: {
    focus: 'series',
    blurScope: 'coordinateSystem'
}

emphasis.blurScope.desc:
Since v5.0.0

The range of fade out when focus is enabled. Support the following configurations

  • 'coordinateSystem'
  • 'series'
  • 'global'

emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

emphasis.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

emphasis.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

emphasis.itemStyle.borderType.desc: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.

emphasis.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

emphasis.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

emphasis.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

emphasis.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

emphasis.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

emphasis.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

emphasis.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

emphasis.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,



}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

emphasis.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

emphasis.label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

emphasis.label.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

emphasis.label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

emphasis.label.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

emphasis.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

emphasis.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

emphasis.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

emphasis.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

emphasis.label.textBorderColor.desc:
Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

emphasis.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

emphasis.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

emphasis.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

emphasis.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

emphasis.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

emphasis.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowO.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

blur.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

blur.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

blur.label.textBorderColor.desc:
Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

blur.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

blur.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

blur.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.verticalAli.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.backgroundC.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffse.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

blur.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

blur.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

blur.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

blur.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

blur.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

blur.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

// Fill with texture

select.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

select.itemStyle.borderType.desc: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.

select.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

select.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

select.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

select.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

select.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named'xxx', for example,{@product}refers the value of'product'` dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index ofn, for example,{@[3]}` refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,



}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

select.areaStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

select.areaStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

select.areaStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

select.areaStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

select.areaStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

selectedMode.desc:
Since v5.0.0

Selected mode. It is enabled by default, and you may set it to be false to disabled it.

Besides, it can be set to 'single' or 'multiple', for single selection and multiple selections.

data.desc:
The data in radar chart is multi-variable (dimension). Here is an example:

data : [
    {
        value : [4300, 10000, 28000, 35000, 50000, 19000],
        name : 'Allocated Budget'
    },
    {
        value : [5000, 14000, 28000, 31000, 42000, 21000],
        name : 'Actual Spending'
    }
]

Among them, value item array contains data that is corresponding to radar.indicator.

data.value.desc: Numerical value of a single data item.

data.symbol.desc:
Symbol of single data.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes

'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

data.symbolSize.desc: single data symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

data.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of single data symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

data.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

data.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of single data symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, [0, '50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

data.label.desc: Style setting of the text on single inflection point.

data.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

data.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

data.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

data.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

data.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

data.label.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

data.label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

data.label.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

data.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

data.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.label.textBorderColor.desc:
Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

data.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

data.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

data.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

data.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

data.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

  • 'bottom'

data.label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffse.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.textBorderC.desc:
Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.textShadowO.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

data.emphasis.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.

    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...

}

data.emphasis.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

data.emphasis.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

data.emphasis.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.emphasis.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

data.select.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

data.select.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

data.select.itemStyle.borderType.desc: Border type, which can be 'solid', 'dashed', or 'dotted'. 'solid' by default.

data.select.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

data.select.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

data.select.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

data.select.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.select.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

data.select.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

data.select.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. Works when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

data.select.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

data.select.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

data.select.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.select.label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

data.select.label.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

data.select.label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

data.select.label.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.select.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.select.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

data.select.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

data.select.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.select.label.textBorderColor.desc:
Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.select.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

data.select.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

data.select.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

data.select.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

data.select.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

data.select.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

text color.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,

}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.select.label.rich.<style_name>.bord.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.select.label.rich.<style_name>.padd.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

data.select.label.rich.<style_name>.shad.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.select.label.rich.<style_name>.widt.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.select.label.rich.<style_name>.heig.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

Storke color of the text.

If set as 'auto', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.select.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

Color can be represented in RGB, for example 'rgb(128, 128, 128)'. RGBA can be used when you need alpha channel, for example 'rgba(128, 128, 128, 0.5)'. You may also use hexadecimal format, for example '#ccc'. Gradient color and texture are also supported besides single colors.

// Linear gradient. First four parameters are x0, y0, x2, and y2, each ranged from 0 to 1, standing for percentage in the bounding box. If global is `true`, then the first four parameters are in absolute pixel positions.
color: {
    type: 'linear',
    x: 0,
    y: 0,
    x2: 0,
    y2: 1,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Radial gradient. First three parameters are x and y positions of center, and radius, similar to linear gradient.
color: {
    type: 'radial',
    x: 0.5,
    y: 0.5,
    r: 0.5,
    colorStops: [{
        offset: 0, color: 'red' // color at 0% position
    }, {
        offset: 1, color: 'blue' // color at 100% position
    }],
    global: false // false by default
}
// Fill with texture
color: {
    image: imageDom, // HTMLImageElement, and HTMLCanvasElement are supported, while string path is not supported
    repeat: 'repeat' // whether to repeat texture, whose value can be repeat-x, repeat-y, or no-repeat
}

Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

data.select.areaStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

data.select.areaStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

data.tooltip.position.desc:
Notice：series.data.tooltip only works when tooltip.trigger is 'item'.

The position of the tooltip's floating layer, which would follow the position of mouse by default.

Options:

  • Array

    Display the position of tooltip's floating layer through array, which supports absolute position and relative percentage.

    Example:

      // absolute position, which is 10px to the left side and 10px to the top side of the container
  position: [10, 10]
  // relative position, in the exact center of the container
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • Function

    Callback function in the following form:

      (point: Array, params: Object|Array.<Object>, dom: HTMLDomElement, rect: Object, size: Object) => Array

    Parameters:
    point: Mouse position.
    param: The same as formatter.
    dom: The DOM object of tooltip.
    rect: It is valid only when mouse is on graphic elements, which stands for a bounding box with x, y, width, and height.
    size: The size of dom echarts container. For example: {contentSize: [width, height], viewSize: [width, height]}.

    Return:
    Return value is an array standing for tooltip position, which can be absolute pixels, or relative percentage.
    Or can be an object, like {left: 10, top: 30}, or {right: '20%', bottom: 40}.

    For example:

      position: function (point, params, dom, rect, size) {
      // fixed at top
      return [point[0], '10%'];
  }

    Or:

      position: function (pos, params, dom, rect, size) {
      // tooltip will be fixed on the right if mouse hovering on the left,
      // and on the left if hovering on the right.
      var obj = {top: 60};
      obj[['left', 'right'][+(pos[0] < size.viewSize[0] / 2)]] = 5;
      return obj;
  }

  • 'inside'

    Center position of the graphic element where the mouse is in, which is only valid when trigger is 'item'.

  • 'top'

    Top position of the graphic element where the mouse is in, which is only valid when trigger is 'item'.

  • 'left'

    Left position of the graphic element where the mouse is in, which is only valid when trigger is 'item'.

  • 'right'

    Right position of the graphic element where the mouse is in, which is only valid when trigger is 'item'.

  • 'bottom'

    Bottom position of the graphic element where the mouse is in, which is only valid when trigger is 'item'.

data.tooltip.formatter.desc:
Notice：series.data.tooltip only works when tooltip.trigger is 'item'.

The content formatter of tooltip's floating layer which supports string template and callback function.

1. String template

The template variables are {a}, {b}, {c}, {d} and {e}, which stands for series name, data name and data value and ect. When trigger is set to be 'axis', there may be data from multiple series. In this time, series index can be refered as {a0}, {a1}, or {a2}.

{a}, {b}, {c}, {d} have different meanings for different series types:

  • Line (area) charts, bar (column) charts, K charts: {a} for series name, {b} for category name, {c} for data value, {d} for none;

  • Scatter (bubble) charts: {a} for series name, {b} for data name, {c} for data value, {d} for none;

  • Map: {a} for series name, {b} for area name, {c} for merging data, {d} for none;

  • Pie charts, gauge charts, funnel charts: {a} for series name, {b} for data item name, {c} for data value, {d} for percentage.

Example: 

formatter: '{b0}: {c0}<br />{b1}: {c1}'

2. Callback function

The format of callback function:

(params: Object|Array, ticket: string, callback: (ticket: string, html: string)) => string

The first parameter params is the data that the formatter needs. Its format is shown as follows:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,


    // the percentage of pie chart
    percent: number,


}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

When trigger is 'axis', or when tooltip is triggered by axisPointer, params is the data array of multiple series. The content of each item of the array is the same as above. Besides,

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string,



}

Note: the usage of encode and dimensionNames can be:

If data is:

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

If data is:

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get values that corresponding to y axis by:

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

Note: Using array to present all the parameters in ECharts 2.x is not supported anymore.

The second parameter ticket is the asynchronous callback flag which should be used along with the third parameter callback when it is used.

The third parameter callback is asynchronous callback. When the content of tooltip is acquired asynchronously, ticket and htm as introduced above can be used to update tooltip with callback.

Example:

formatter: function (params, ticket, callback) {
    $.get('detail?name=' + params.name, function (content) {
        callback(ticket, toHTML(content));
    });
    return 'Loading';
}

The floating layer of tooltip space around content. The unit is px. Default values for each position are 5. And they can be set to different values with left, right, top, and bottom.

Examples: 

// Set padding to be 5

// Set the top and bottom paddings to be 5, and left and right paddings to be 10

// Set each of the four paddings seperately
padding: [
    5,  // up
    10, // right
    5,  // down
    10, // left
]

data.tooltip.textStyle.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

data.tooltip.textStyle.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
